After his death we have faced very poor financial conditions. Last year, I bought a cow by obtaining a credit from Asasah, a microfinance institution. At present, I request another loan to buy an additional cow. I request loans for few of the other women: Fozia B. and Sughran B. request loans to buy cows. Riaz B. would like to get a new cabin for their rickshaw which is used by passengers to sit. Soba B. would use the loan to buy goats for the business.

loans.use: To buy an additional cow

loans.name: Abdumahmad

texts.ru:
Abdumahmad was born in 1971, married and has been in the animal husbandry business for the past 10 years. He has a large piece of land attached to his house where he breeds his livestock. At this time he has four bulls and two cows. Last fall one of the cows gave birth to a calve and now Abdumahmad's family has fresh milk every morning.

His wife milks the cow and his children feed the animals and help their father clean up. After the bulls have grown he sells them and buys a new set of calves for continuous business.

Abdumahmad has been taking out loans since March 10, 2007 and has been successfully paying them off. He has also applied for a loan in Kiev to buy fodder for livestock and coal to heat the byre.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдумахмад,1971 года рождения,женат,занимается животноводством уже 10 лет.Он имеет большой двор около своего дома,где он держит свой скот. На данный период он имеет 4-х быков и две коровы.Этой осенью у одной коровы родился один теленок и теперь семья Абдумахмуда имеет свежее молоко каждое утро.

Жена доит корову,а дети дают корм и убирают за скотом вместе с отцом.После откорма он продает быков и сразу же закупает новую партию молодняков для дальнейшего бизнеса.

В нашей органзации он кредитуется с 10.03.2007 успешно пагашает свой займ.В КИВЕ он захотел участвовать для получения займа на покупку корма и углей для обогрева коровника.

loans.use: To purchase fodder for bulls.

loans.name: Ugil

texts.en:
Ugil is 57 years old. She and her husband have raised nine children. Ugil is a market vendor. Every day, early in the morning, Ugil goes to the city bus station in order to meet her suppliers. She purchases eggs, chicken and dairy products for low wholesale prices. Then she sells all the goods in the local market for retail prices. Ugil's son and daughter help her in the business. Ugil's husband is a pensioner, so the current business is the main source of income for the family.

Ugil has borrowed from IMON several times and she expresses her gratitude to the organization, stating that with the help of IMON she was able to develop her business and to have the funds for purchasing her goods. Now she requests 600.00 Somoni (US$175.00 ) for 4 months. Ugil thanks all for support and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase wholesale products for sale

loans.name: Maarufu's Ujamaa Group

texts.en:
M. M. is 32 years old, married and has two children, who are 10 and 3 years old. For the past six years, he has made a living selling secondhand clothing. He works from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily, and is able to make a monthly profit of about $254.

M. has applied for a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase the stock of clothing he has for sale. He will share this loan with his group members, and they will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

In the picture, M. is in the back row, second from the left.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothing to sell

loans.name: Nangialy

texts.en: This is Nangialy, the son of R. D.. Nangialy lives in the district of Shewa in the Ningarhar province. Nangialy operates a retail food shop near his house, but he does not generate enough income to solve his economic problems because there are not enough products for sale in his shop. As such, he is hoping to increase his income by purchasing more food for his shop. Specifically, he is seeking a loan in the amount of 50,000 Afghanis ($1,050) through AFSG to resolve the issues he faces in connection with his small business.

loans.use: To generate more income by purchasing additional food and materials for his shop

loans.name: Akouélé Léontine

texts.fr:
Born December 31st, 1968 in Aklakougan in Togo, Mrs. Akouélé Léontine is married and the mother of two children. Since 1999, she has been running a shop selling ready-to-wear clothing not far from Lomé’s main market. In her ready-to-wear shop (ETS LEONCE), one can find fabric, shoes, clothing, scarves, etc. She orders goods from China so that she can sell cheaply and allow everyone to be able to shop and dress. This is her second loan and she is seeking to borrow 500,000 Francs CFA to supplement her own financing in order to be able to buy five bulk bundles of clothing.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer

Née le 31 décembre 1968 à Aklakougan au Togo, Madame S. Akouélé Léontine est mariée et a deux (2) enfants. Depuis 1999, elle a ouvert une boutique de vente de prêt-à-porter non loin du grand marché de Lomé. Dans sa boutique de prêt-à-porter (ETS LEONCE), on peut trouver des pagnes, des chaussures, des vêtements, des foulards etc. Elle fait sa commande depuis la chine afin de pouvoir vendre moins cher et permettre à tout le monde de pouvoir se vertir. Elle est à son 2ème crédit et sollicite un crédit de 500.000FCFA pour augmenter son fonds propres afin de pouvoir faire des achats de 5 ballots de vêtements.

loans.use: Purchase of five bulk bundles of clothing

loans.name: Santa Juliana

texts.es:
Santa Juliana is very popular at the Cerro Colorado market in the city of Juliaca. After she gave birth to her beloved children, she decided to leave her hometown of Huata with the hope of finding a better future for them. This devoted mother began selling groceries as a street vendor until she had enough savings to acquire a stall in the market. Currently, Santa Juliana’s stall is very busy with customers who are well satisfied with the affordable prices and with the attention they receive from her. Thanks to the income from her business, she succeeded in providing a good education for her three children who are now all professionals and independent. The greatest treasure of this loving and charming woman is her grandson who has become the light of her life and for whom she wants to proviD. security and tranquility. She hopes that with your support, she will be able to expand her business, buy merchandise and increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Melissa Hays, Kiva Volunteer.

Santa Juliana es muy popular y querida dentro del mercado Cerro Colorado D. la ciudad D. Juliaca, desD. que les dio el don D. vida a sus queridos hijos decidió abandonar su pueblo natal, Huata, con la esperanza D. buscar un mejor porvenir para los suyos.Esta diligente y amorosa madre se inició vendiendo abarrotes en forma ambulatoria, luego D. ahorrar lo suficiente pudo finalmente adquirir un puestito D. venta al interior del mercado. Actualmente su puesto es muy concurrido por sus clientes, clientes que se sienten satisfechos por los cómodos precios y buena atención que reciben D. esta esmerada madre. Gracias a este negocio, logró brindarle estudios superiores a sus 3 hijos, quienes ya son profesionales e independientes.El tesoro más granD. D. esta amorosa y encantadora mujer su querido nieto, quien se convirtió en la alegría D. su vida y a quien desea ofrecer seguridad y tranquilidad, espera que con el apoyo que reciba D. vosotros pueda ampliar su negocio, comprar mercadería y mejorar sus ingresos económicos.

loans.use: To increase the merchandise at her grocery stall in order to provide a secure future for her beloved grandson.

loans.name: Irma Karina

texts.en:
Karina is not a typical Kiva client, but like almost all Kiva clients, she faces many challenges and is fighting to develop a business and improve her life. Karina is a prisoner at the Santa Teresa Preventative Center for Rehabilitation in Guatemala City. She says that she has committed errors in her life but is now working to change and improve her life and her future. The Guatemalan government provides food and the most basic necessities for prisoners, but the food amount is small and of very bad quality. Therefore, prisoners usually need a little of their own money to supplement what they receive from the prison. As a result, many prisoners in the Santa Teresa women’s prison have businesses within the jail, as is common in much of the developing world.

Karina is very entrepreneurial and already has two businesses. She works making arts and crafts to sell within the prison and is trying to set up a way to sell them outside as well. Additionally she sells juices within the jail. In the past she had access to another prisoner’s freezer to cool the juice, but that prisoner left and took the freezer with her. Obviously Karina can sell much more juice if it is cold, so she is requesting this loan to purchase a refrigerator. She has already researched her options for refrigerators and has found a high quality used refrigerator and has also already gotten permission from the prison administration to bring it into the jail. The refrigerator will cost 3,000 Guatemala Quetzals (approximately USD $400) and she will use the rest of her loan to buy more juice to sell. She tries to maintain a stock of high quality juice and a good variety, such as pineapple, peach, and pear juice in addition to orange juice, apple juice, and Gatorade. Karina also works to find the best prices for the juices and can currently buy many of the juices for 1.90 Quetzals each and sell them for 4 Quetzals each, a good return.

Karina has many dreams of how to improve her life and what she can do when she is able to leave jail. She has already studied to be a secretary, but she wants to continue studying to specialize in computers and would also like to study English. She wants to start a business selling clothes and has already though a lot about various strategies that she could implement to develop and improve this business. She would also like to have a kiosk to sell the arts and crafts that she already makes.

FAPE has just gotten permission from the Guatemalan government to loan money to prisoners in Santa Teresa and is also working with the government to provide training for starting a business. They also are hoping to offer more training to improve businesses in the future. Although these clients are not typical microfinance clients, like all FAPE clients, they can only receive loans if they have a business or have the desire to start a business and a good plan to do it.

Karina is extremely appreciative to have the opportunity to receive a loan to invest in her business. When she leaves prison, she is going to face many challenges trying to reestablish her life. She says that she is trying to start to save and plan now to be able to be successful when she is able to leave. FAPE’s training and her business that she is going to expand with the help of this loan are going to help her a lot to have more knowledge, experience, and maybe even a little money to help her get her new life started. Furthermore, she will be able to take the refrigerator with her when she leaves jail. Karina is very committed to reintegrating into society and never returning to prison. Additionally, she says that she is very grateful to FAPE and to Kiva for giving her opportunities to rise above her mistakes and that these opportunities are like a light and a great blessing.

To learn a little more about Santa Teresa and FAPE’s program there, you can go to this blog to read some observations from a Kiva Fellow: A Day in Prison

Translated from Spanish by Megan Montgomery, Kiva Fellow.

Karina no es una clienta Kiva típica, pero como casi todos los clientes Kiva tiene varios desafíos y está luchando de desarrollar un negocio y mejorar su vida. Karina es una presa en el Centro Preventivo de Rehabilitación Santa Teresa en la ciudad capital de Guatemala. Ella dice que ha cometido errores en su vida, pero ahora está trabajando para cambiar y mejorar su vida y su futura. El gobierno Guatemalteco provee comida y la necesidades más básicos para los presos, pero la comida es poco y de muy mala calidad. Entonces, las presas suelen necesitar un poco de su propio dinero para complementar lo que reciben de la cárcel. Por lo tanto, muchas de las presas en la cárcel de mujeres en Santa Teresa tienen negocios dentro de la cárcel, como es común en mucho del mundo en desarrollo.

Karina es muy emprendedora y ya tiene dos negocios. Trabaja en hacer manualidades que vende dentro de la cárcel y esta tratando de arreglar una manera de venderlas afuera también. Además, tiene una venta de jugos dentro de la cárcel. En el pasado, tenía acceso a un congelador de otra presa para enfriarlos, pero ella se fue y llevó su congelador con ella. Obviamente Karina puede vender mucho más jugo si está frio, entonces está pidiendo este préstamo para comprar un refrigerador. Ella ya ha investigado sus opciones para refrigeradores y ha encontrado un refrigerador usado pero de buena calidad y ya ha conseguido el permiso de la administración de la cárcel para traerlo en la cárcel. El refrigerador costará 3.000 Quetzales Guatemaltecos (aproximadamente USD $400) y utilizará el resto de su préstamo para comprar más jugos para vender. Ella trata de mantener una reserva de jugos de buena calidad y variedad, como de piña, melocotón, y pera, además de jugos de naranja, manzana y Gatorades. Karina también trabaja para encontrar los mejores precios para los jugos, y ahora puede comprar muchos de los jugos por 1.90 Quetzales y los puede vender por 4 Quetzales, un rendimiento bueno.

Karina tiene muchos sueños de cómo puede mejorar su vida y que puede hace cuando puede salir de la cárcel. Ella ya es secretaria, pero quiere estudiar la computación para especializar y también le gustaría estudiar el inglés. Quiere iniciar un negocio de venta de ropa y ya ha pensado mucho en varias estrategias que se puede implementar para desarrollar y mejorar este negocio. También quiere tener un quiosco para vender las manualidades como las que ya produce.

FAPE acaba de conseguir el permiso del gobierno Guatemalteco para poder prestar dinero a las presas de Santa Teresa y también está trabajando con el gobierno para ofrecer capacitaciones de cómo iniciar un negocio, y tiene ganas de ofrecer más capacitaciones de cómo mejorar un negocio en el futuro. Aunque estos clientes no son clientes de microfinanzas típicos, a la misma vez solamente se puede recibir préstamos si tiene un negocio o tiene ganas de empezar un negocio y un buen plan para hacerlo.

Karina está extremadamente agradecida de tener la oportunidad de recibir crédito para invertir en su negocio. Cuando sale de la cárcel, va a tener muchas desafíos en tratando de restablecer su vida. Dice que está tratando de empezar a ahorrar y planear ahora para poder tener éxito cuando puede salir. Las capacitaciones de FAPE y su negocio que va a aumentar con la ayuda de este préstamo van a ayudarle muchísimo en tener más conocimiento, experiencia, y quizás un poco de dinero para ayudarle en empezando su vida nueva. Además, podrá sido llevar el refrigerador con ella cuando sale de la cárcel. Karina dice que es muy cometida de reintegrar en la sociedad y nunca regresar a la cárcel. Además, dice que le agradece a FAPE y a Kiva por darle oportunidades de superarse de sus errores y sirven como una luz y una gran bendición.

Para aprender up poco más de Santa Teresa y el programa de FAPE allá, se puede ir a este blog para leer algunas observaciones de una Kiva Fellow: Un Día en la Cárcel

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator and juice to sell

loans.name: Mayde

texts.es:
Mayde es productora de leche de vaca y pequeña agricultora de hortalizas (trabaja con la ayuda de hijo mayor de 14 años), sul esposo migró hacia la Republica de Argentina para poder trabajar de costurero (envía dinero mensualmente para mantener a sus tres hijos). Mayde vive en la Comunidad de Palomar a dos horas y media de la Ciudad de La Paz.

El crédito sera usado para comprar una vaca de mediana calidad, su intención es generar mayores ingresos económicos.
 
Es su primer crédito con Impro, esta calificada para obtener el préstamo
texts.en:
Mayde is a small vegetable farmer and processes cows' milk (she works with help from her 14 year old son). Her husband migrated to Argentina to work sewing (he sends money monthly to maintain their 3 kids). Mayde lives in the Community of Palomar, two and a half hours from the city of La Paz.

The credit will be used to buy a medium quality cow and her intention is to generate more economic income.

This is her first credit with Impro, and she is qualified to get a loan.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a milk-giving cow/COMPRA DE VACA LECHERA

loans.name: Soloiluma

texts.en:
Soloiluma L., 70, is married with 8 children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and the public 6 days per week. She has 6 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

SPBD loans are Soloiluma's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used to repair her house. Her husband does all the farming.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, gromozone, weedkiller, knives; also to fund home repair

loans.name: Mwanaulu

texts.en:
Mwanaulu S. has been selling fish in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. She works from 6:00 am to 4:00 pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $45 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fish to sell and increase her sales and profit.

Mwanaulu is 30 years old, divorced, and has three children, aged 3, 5, and 7.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac G. is a 45-year-old sign writer and taxi driver. Isaac is married with three kids; two are still in school. 

For the past 25 years, Isaac has been in the business of screen printing – banners, handkerchiefs, t-shirts, etc., and also writing signboards for the people in his community. According to him, he is the pioneer in his community as far as sign writing is concerned and has trained a number of artists in his town and nearby towns. 

Isaac says he has to travel to the city where he will have access to the developing machine (a device used to copy or transfer paper designs onto the screen) and also buy the materials he will need (mesh, white wood glue, print paste, potassium dichromate, etc). Isaac desires to acquire his own developing machine, which will save him the trouble of traveling to have his screens developed. He says he can also develop for other screen printers for a fee. 

He wants a loan to buy this device and also some of the materials he works with. Isaac belongs to the group called “Victory Trust Group” which is made up of only five members. The group members guarantee one another as collateral to access the loan.

loans.use: To expand his printing business.

loans.name: Oung

texts.en:
Mrs. Oung S. is 28 years old and raises pigs to sell. She lives in Kampong Thom Province. She is married to Mr. Nut Phorn, a house roofing constructor in Phnom Penh City. Her husband has a lot of experience with this job and his work is recognized for its good quality. He moves to work depending on work requirements.

S. does not have any children and lives only with her husband. With her saved money, S. has so far built a part of a house but is not finished yet. Hence, she would like to request a loan to purchase wood to finish her house building.

loans.use: To purchase wood to finish her house building.

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer T. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through senior high. Since 2002, Jenifer has been selling fridges, television sets and other home appliances at Ayiko-Ayikoo. Her husband is a mechanic.

Jenifer uses her income to support her husband in paying the rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Jenifer will use this loan to buy more home appliances to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Jenifer plans to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: To buy more home appliances to sell

loans.name: Matilde

texts.es: Matilde es una mujer de 31 años, muy persistente en sus objetivos, vive en un cuarto de manera independiente, el cual alquiló cuando se vino de su querido Huancané (Provincia de Puno). Su actividad principal es el tejido artesanal, ella se gana la vida haciendo chullos (Prenda de vestir para cubrir la cabeza), chompas, guantes, etc, es una tejedora muy ágil y rápida, vende sus artesanías en su propio cuarto, ya que esta ubicado cerca de uno de los mercado más grandes de Juliaca. Ella aprendió a tejer de su madre ya que es la actividad familiar a la que se dedicaban en Huancané. Matilde gusta de tejer, sabe que mientras más lo haga, sus tejidos serán mejores, pero le es muy difícil cortar las figuritas que usa para adornar sus artesanías, ya que tiene que hacerlo con mucho cuidado para no dañarlas, con los 12 años de experiencia en este trabajo, a decidido hacer crecer su negocio y espera para un futuro cercano, tener una tienda más grande, donde pueda vender sus tejidos con mayor comodidad. Es el quinto préstamo de Matilde en MFP, ella siempre ahorra dinero de sus ventas para poder pagar sus cuotas a tiempo, es una socia muy amable y alegre, que siempre trabaja por el bienestar de su banco comunal. Con este nuevo préstamo, Matilde ha decidido comprar más lana para hacer sus tejidos, lo cual le costara aproximadamente mil soles, con el resto del préstamo hará arreglar sus máquinas de tejer.
texts.en:
Matilde is a 31 year old woman who is very persistant with her goals. She lives independently in a room that she rented when she left her lovely city of Huancané (in the Puno Province). Her main job is as an artisan knitter and she earns her living making wool hats, sweaters, gloves, etc. She is an efficient and precise knitter and she sells her products from her home since it is located near one of the largest markets in the city of Juliaca. She learned to knit from her mother as this is what her family does in Huancané. Matilde likes to knit and knows that her products look better when she adds little figures as decoration. It is hard to cut out the little figurines and she has to be very careful not to damage them. With 12 years of experience, she is now dedicated to growing her business and improving her future. In the near future she would like to have a bigger, more comfortable shop to sell her products. This is her fifth loan with MFP and she always saves the money from her sales in order to make her payments on time. She is an active member of her community bank who is always friendly and happy. With this loan, Matilde will buy more wool for her products, which will cost about 1,000 soles. With the rest of the money she will make repairs to her weaving machines.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wool and repair her weaving machines

loans.name: Tuk's Group
loans.use: To renovate her house and build another kitchen room.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.es: Lucy tiene 32 años de edad, vive con su pareja y padre de sus 4 hijos en una casa alquilada. Ambos son artesanos, su esposo teje mantas y frazadas en un telar grande, y ella es especialista en tapices geométricos, con un telar pequeño. Lucy no necesita apoyarse de ningún cuadro ni fotografía para realizar las diversas combinaciones de las figuras y los colores, porque dice tenerlo todo en su mente y solo necesita un poco de concentración. Este trabajo lo desarrolla por más de 20 años, lo que le ha permitido ganarse el reconocimiento de sus paisanos por tal habilidad. En el mes de marzo los tapices son muy rentables, pero su dificultad mayor es la falta de dinero para producir en grandes cantidades, por ello teje solo a pedido, por el que le adelantan la cuarta parte del precio. El trabajo de esta pareja de artesanos les sirve para solventar los gastos domésticos y la educación de sus hijos. En los ciclos anteriores, Lucy tuvo el cargo de vocal en su banco comunal, cumpliendo correctamente con la labor encomendada. Este es su 3er préstamo con MFP, y en todo este tiempo demostró responsabilidad es sus pagos. El dinero que solicita lo empleará en la compra de materiales para la producción de más tapices, debido a la cercanía de las festividades de semana santa, donde hay mayor demanda.
texts.en:
Lucy is 32 years old and lives with her common law husband and their 4 children in a rented house. They are both artisans—her husband makes blankets and comforters with a large weaver and she is a specialist in small wall hangings, made with a small weaver. Lucy does not need the help of any paintings or pictures to make the varied combinations of colors and designs on her wall hangings. She says she has all of the designs in her mind and only needs to concentrate. She has been making textiles for more than 20 years, and her abilities have earned her the recognition of her peers. In the month of March her pieces are very profitable, but her greatest difficulty is that she lacks the money to produce large quantities. For large orders, she only makes custom orders and requires one fourth of the cost up front. The work of this artisan couple allows them to pay their household expenses and to provide an education for their children. In earlier loan cycles, Lucy was the spokeswoman for her community bank, where she successfully completed her required duties. This is her 3rd loan with MFP and she has always been responsible with her payments. The money that she is asking for will be used to buy materials to make more wall hangings, since Easter is coming up and there is more demand for her work.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Weaving materials

loans.name: Bisoliha

texts.en:
J. Bisoliha has been an active and one of oldest clients of MicroInvest. She applied first to MicroInvest in 2002. She lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan and she trades in the local bazaar selling fruits and dry fruits. Bisoliha has been engaged in fruit selling for 6 years. She works closely with collective farmers so she has the opportunity to trade with lower prices than the bazaar prices.

Bisoliha applies to Kiva with the request of a business support loan of 1600 TJS for 6 months for to increase her area of trade. She thanks Kiva for its support of small business development.

loans.use: To increase her area of trade

loans.name: John

texts.en: John A. is single, has one child and has received schooling through senior high school. Since 2005, John has worked as a businessman in Elmina, doing jobs such as photocopying and typing. John uses his income to pay for his family’s bills and will use this loan to purchase new machines to expand and improve his business. With his newly gained profits, John plans to purchase additional items to aid in his future success and also to further expand his enterprise.

loans.use: To purchase business machines.

loans.name: Julia Yamileth

texts.es:
La señora Julia S. se dedica a atender su negocio de pulpería en la ciudad de Chinandega y específicamente en el municipio de Chichigalpa donde a diario ofrece los diferentes productos comestibles a sus clientes. Ella ha sido una excelente trabajadora habiendo mejorado su condición económica gracias a los créditos que le ha brindado Ceprodel.

Hoy en día, una vez más ha espera muy confiadamente en que su crédito le será otorgado y así saldrá adelante en el negocio mejorando su condición y beneficiando a su amada familia que está a su cargo.
texts.en:
Julia S. dedicates herself to looking after her grocery store in the city of Chinandega, located in the municipality of Chichigalpa. Daily she offers various food products to her customers. She has been an excellent worker having improved her economic condition through the loans provided by Ceprodel. Today, once again she confidently expects that she will obtain a loan so that she can succeed in her business improving her status and thus benefiting her beloved family that she cares for.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products for her grocery store.

loans.name: Bahrom

texts.en:
Since he was a young man, Bahrom has known how to work hard. His parents taught him how to get by as an agriculturist, and he learned very well. Now that he is the father of a family, he still works as an agriculturalist. Thanks to his parents, Bahrom now has the opportunity to move forward as a farmer, and he hopes to increase his agricultural produce so that he can bring his loved ones a more promising life.

Despite being a good agriculturalist and worker he needs help to move forward and improve his production. This is why he is asking for a loan, so that he can buy more of the seeds and fertilizers he needs, which are very expensive, but without them his production will not improve. You can help Bahrom keep moving forward with his development plans.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Mahammad

texts.en:
Mahammad M. is 56 years old. He is married and has three sons. 

Mahammad sells cattle. As a rule he purchases calves in the central market, feeds them and then resells them at higher prices in the local market. 

Having been in this business for eight years he knows very well how to choose the animals, how to raise them and look after them. He gets up every morning in order to feed the animals and to look after them. His knowledge and skills allow him to make his business successful and to generate a considerable and stable income for his large family. 

Mahammad is planning to enlarge the stock and to purchase more cattle. For this purpose he requests a $2000 loan that he will use to purchase four calves. You can play an important part in Mahammad’s family's life and he deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

loans.use: To purchase four calves to raise

loans.name: Yaqub

texts.en: Yaqub N. is a 56-year-old married father of three children. He provides for his family with the revenue generated by the grocery store he owns. He is requesting a loan of $2000 US to increase the stock of food goods available at his store. Yaqub is ready to work even harder and make sacrifices to achieve his goal of becoming a successful entrepreneur and supporting his children's efforts to get good educations. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will ensure the success of his small business.

loans.use: To purchase more food products for inventory

loans.name: Esther

texts.es:
Esther es socia del Bancomunal Siempre Juntas.
Esther  es madre soltera tiene 51 años, una hija de 29 años que trabaja. 
Esther  es de Huancayo es profesora, pero cuando llego a Lima dejo de trabajar por que se caso y se dedico a cuidar a su hija, pero se separa de su esposo y  se pone a trabajar en la venta de abarrotes y de plásticos tiene un puesto en  una feria desde hace 25 años. 
Desde que Esther esta en Finca  aprendió a trabajar y a ser responsable con el pago.
Esther necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles, para comprar abarrotes y platos, descartables, bolsas. 
El sueño de Esther es tener otro puesto de trabajo.
texts.en:
Esther is a member of the Always Together (Siempre Juntas) Community Bank. She is 51 years old and is a single mother of a 29-year-old daughter, who is working. Esther is from Huancayo and was a teacher, but when she came to Lima, she stopped working because she got married and was taking care of her daughter. When she and her husband separated, however, she started selling groceries and plastic products. She has had a stand in a fair for 25 years. Since she has been with Finca, Esther has learned to work and to be responsible with repayments. Esther needs a loan of 1600 soles to buy groceries, plates, disposable products, and bags. Her dream is to have another stand for her work.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groceries, plates, disposable products, and bags

loans.name: Phim's Group

texts.en: Always almost of the every dawn and late afternoon of the day, M. rushes to the riverside gather the fishes from her husband Bro, 28, on the a small fishing boat and hurries to the market selling at retails so that she will get a high suitable price. M. in the age of 29 years old has given birth to four children all of whom are still young and attend school. The family has now all of the fishing materials because of the great success they achieve. M. is asking for a loan to invest the selling of her fish to a more greater. She only dream of having degree for her children. She is a leader the other four members of the group. They are Khum, N., T., and S. all of whom spend their almost life on the water too. T. was not available during the photograph so her husband is taken instead.

loans.use: to invest the selling of her fish to a more greater.

loans.name: Ebere

texts.en: Ebere sells rechargeable phones and phones accessories to make a living. This business needs a greater variety of merchandise. Ebere does not have the money to invest. That is why she is asking for a loan to be able to stock her shop. Ebere is 31 years old and married with a child. Ebere hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more rechargeable phones and accessories to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phones and accessories to sell

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is a widow. She has one grown son and one who is still in school. Tatyana’s life has never been easy. After the loss of her husband she had to take on full responsibility for her boys. This is how she decided to launch her own small business selling womens' footwear in the central retail market of Zaporozhye.

Tatyana has been in the trade for 15 years. She has a lot of experience working with different customers and various types of inventory. Presently, her turnover capital amounts to 40,000 UAH. Her net profit is about 3,000 UAH a month.

Tatyana is seeking a loan of 11,700 UAH to purchase assorted fall and winter merchandise. She has repaid all her previous loans without any delinquencies which characterizes her as a responsible and solvent borrower. We believe Tatyana’s determination and balanced business approach will help her repay the current loan without any problems as well.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Mohammad Nazar

texts.en:
Mohammad Nazar is a young man. He is uneducated but he has lots of experience. He has a cosmetics and ladies purse shop in the city of Jalalabad. He has been involved in this business for more than 5 years, and earlier he worked in another similar business in the same city. He has responsibility for his family, so during the last 5 years, he tried many times to enlarge his shop, but was unable to do so. When he found AFS (Ariana Financial Services Joint Stock Company) in Jalalabad, he was very happy and decided to apply for a loan.

He has requested an individual loan of 30000 Afghans to buy some necessary tools for his cosmetics shop and to enlarge his shop. These improvements will further his business, helping him be more successful and make a good monthly income for his family.

loans.use: To buy some necessary tools for his cosmetics shop and to enlarge the shop

loans.name: 02.1.8 Nam Ngan Group

texts.en:
Vinh Lê Thị is a 46-year-old female living in the town of T. Hoá. Vinh is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02.1.8 Nam Ngạn.

Vinh is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Vinh makes and sells food. The main source of income for her business comes from selling rice products in the local community. Vinh has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 1500000 Vietnamese dong a month from these activities.

In 2009, Vinh joined T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vinh is requesting a loan from T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women for the first time. She is requesting a new loan of 3000000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. Vinh plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1. Lê Thị Phúc is a 59-year-old female who is requesting a 3000000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

2. Lê Thị T. Giang is an 18-year-old female who is requesting a 3000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

About T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of the T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the T. Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

================================

Vinh Lê Thị (47) là 46 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố T. Hoá.  Vinh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02.1.8 Nam Ngạn.


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ gạo trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Vinh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Vinh kiếm được khoảng 1500000 VND.  Vào 2009, Vinh đã tham gia T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Vinh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 3,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Lê Thị Phúc (48) là 59 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


2.  Lê Thị T. Giang (49) là 18 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về T. Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo T. Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh T. Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Eudricelo

texts.en:
Eudricelo L. is from the city of Labo Ozamiz City. He is 44 years old. Eudricelo is married and has 3 school-aged children. Eudricelo owns & operates a "sari-sari" retail store where he sells a variety of different products in the local community. Eudricelo has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Eudricelo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to engage in business activities. Eudricelo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. He is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Eudricelo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Davaasuren

texts.en:
Davaasuren is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two sons, 17 and 11, both attend a local secondary school and her husband mines for gold. Davaasuren operates a clothing retail business in her town where she imports products from China and sells the items at the local market. She started her business in 2003 with working capital of 600,000 tugrugs (~420 USD) and at first she had difficulty importing her merchandise, but now she has both reliable customers and suppliers. Now her working capital exceeds 3,000,000 tugrugs (~2100 USD) and she has managed to buy a car for her family with her business’ profits. She says, “I work hard in order to save money for my children’s education.” Davaasuren is requesting a 1,550,000 tugrug (~1090 USD) loan in order to import more products from China. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To import more products from China.

loans.name: Roger Jose

texts.es:
El Señor Roger José Gutiérrez O., Labora como conductor de la Universidad Nacional de Ingeniería, el tiene a su cargo tres hijos, dos de ellos se encuentran en edad escolar, es soltero, ha trabajado créditos con CEPRODEL durante tres años, en ese lapso ha invertido  3 créditos en la mejora de las condiciones de su vivienda otorgados por CEPRODEL, el es una excelente Cliente.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales para la remodelación del piso de su  vivienda y el pago de la mano obra, para darles una mejor condición de vida a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Sr. Roger José Gutiérrez O. works as a driver for the National University of Engineering. He has three children, two of whom are of school age. Roger is single.

During the three years he has worked with CEPRODEL, Roger used his previous three loans to invest in home improvements. He is an excellent client. The loan he is now requesting will be used to buy construction materials for refurbishing his floor and to pay for labor. This will provide better living conditions for his children.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for materials & labor needed to refurbish his floors

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of tufts of hair

loans.name: Acuario2 Group

texts.es:
El grupo Acuario 2 está integrado por Rosa María Gaitán G., Manuela de Jesús Jiménez y Rosa Amanda Suárez tres mujeres trabajadoras y emprendedoras.  Gaitán es la coordinadora del grupo esta señora hace dos años invirtió sus pequeños ahorro en la compra de cerdo para su destace y venta en el cual le a ido bien.

Por su parte Manuela de Jesús Jiménez en 1992 empezó a comercializar bisutería de manera ambulante con el tiempo  gracias a su esfuerzo, trabajo y dedicación logro tener pequeño tramo en mercadito de Managua. Mientras Rosa Amanda desde hace diez año vende tortilla en su casa.
texts.en:
The group Acuario 2 includes Rosa María Gaitán G., Manuela de Jesús Jiménez and Rosa Amanda Suárez, three hard-working and entrepreneurial women. Gaitán is the group coordinator. Two years ago, she invested her small savings into the purchase of pigs to butcher and sell, a business which has served her well. With regards to Manuela de Jesús Jiménez, in 1992 she started to sell jewelry from door to door. With time, thanks to her effort, hard work, and dedication, she has been able to set up a small stand in Managua's marketplace. Meanwhile, Rosa Amanda has been selling tortillas out of her home for ten years.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pigs

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria G. is from the village of Upper Carmen, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 53 years old. Victoria is a widow with six adult children. To make a living, Victoria buys and sells rice in the local community. Victoria has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Victoria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Victoria from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Carmen, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Women In Action 2 Group

texts.es:
El comité “Mujeres en Acción”se formó gracias al deseo de superación y mejoramiento de la calidad de vida de sus integrantes  . 
Entre las actividades de las que realizan las estudiante se destacan venta de frutas y verduras , venta de comestibles artesanales como empanadas de carne ,empanadas de pollo ,empanadas de jamón y queso ,venta de mercaderías varias como :fideo ,azúcar , harina ,aceite, jabón, entre otros artículos ,venta de ropas , venta de remedios etc.
Anhelan un futuro mejor para sus hijos, es por eso que se esfuerzan el doble para facilitarles los materiales  para  su desarrollo y formación.     
La Sra. Jazmín quien se dedica a la venta de ropas, ella ofrece sus mercaderías en su casa y al mismo tiempo realiza otras actividades para aumentar su venta como la visita a clientes.
Las actividades que cada una realiza se detalla a continuación:

texts.en:
The group “Women in Action” formed thanks to the desire to overcome and improve the quality of life of its members. Among the businesses are sales of: fruit and vegetables; handmade meat pies; groceries such as noodles, sugar, flour, oil, and soap; clothing; herbal remedies; etc. They long for a better future for their children, which is why they work twice as hard on the materials for their development and formation. Senora Jazmín, who sells clothing, sells from her home, and she also visits her clients to increase her sales. The activities of each member are detailed below: 1 Jasmin V. - Clothing 2 Gloria D. - Aperitifs 3 Amalia O. - Kiosk 4 Adela C. - Street vendor of costume jewelry 5 Gabriela C. - Vegetables 6 Zunilda C. - Clothing 7 Marilina C. - Clothing 8 Felicia D. - Pantry items 9 Rosa V. - Sewing supplies 10 Daiane D. - Fruit 11 Juana I. - Chips 12 Crescencia F. - Meat pies 13 Lucina C. - Herbal remedies 14 Lourdes C. - Sewing supplies 15 Limpia A. - Fashion 16 Yessica J. - Recycling

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of business stock

loans.name: Hikoyatullo

texts.en: Hikoyatullo Y. is 29 years old. He is married and has the business of baking “lepeshka,” the national bread. Hikoyatullo is the main breadwinner in the family. He believes that this business is profitable and is not subject to seasonality. He gets up early and bakes the lepeshka and bread so that people have fresh bread on their tables for breakfast. All the input materials like the flour, salt and yeast, he purchases in the local market. Now due to high demand, Hikoyatullo wants to increase the number of breads he can make, so he requests 4700 Somoni. The loan will be spent on flour and on coal for baking the “lepeshka.” Hikoyatullo deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him. More about Tajikistan Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing flour for baking the national bread, “lepeshka”

loans.name: Burema Women's Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
M. Medius is 32 years old and married with five children aged 12, 9, 7, 5 and 1 year. She also takes care of three orphans.

Medius has operated a retail shop in Burema for two years from which she is able to make 30,000/= as weekly profits although she has some defaulters who affect her cash flow. She has good customer care and she would like to expand her business into a wholesale business and have all her children attain the best education.

Medius sells general merchandise like sugar, salt, cooking oil, bread and so on and she hopes to expand her business by having more purchases for an improved stock. Medius appears in the group photo and is also shown at the top left. She is a very hardworking lady with a strong drive to succeed.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to expand her shop

loans.name: Hean

texts.en: Mrs. V. is 23 years old and a resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She is the mother of four children who are students at the secondary school. She is married to Nara, who is 30 years old and a machinery repairman. To earn her daily revenue, V. goes to buy chickens in bulk at low prices from the rural people and then sells the chickens at retail prices at the market for a profit, earning about $6 a day. Recently V. received orders from her customers for a hundred kg of chickens, but she lacks the cash to buy enough chickens to fill her customers' requests. Therefore, V. is applying for a loan of $300 to serve as capital so that she can buy more chickens for her clients. V.'s husband appears at the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more chickens to sell.

loans.name: Blanca Esthela

texts.es: Blanca Esthela es una mujer joven que tiene muchos proyectos para apoyar  su esposo para ayudarlo con los gastos del hogar. Ella cuenta con negocio de la venta de gorditas y platillos los cuales ofrece en las maquiladoras por pedido. Ahora a ella le esta ofreciendo una carrucha  para adaptar a la  su camioneta en la que le puede poner un anuncio ofreciendo el producto y así obtener mas ingresos.
texts.en:
Blancha Esthela is a young woman who has a lot of projects so that she can support her husband and help him with household expenses. She has a business selling gorditas (a typical Mexican dish) and meals ordered by workers in assembly plants. Now she is being offered a cart that can be attached to her pickup truck. She will put a sign on this offering her products and, thus, obtain more income

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a cart for her business.

loans.name: Maria Azucena

texts.es:
La señora Maria Azucena C. O., tiene 44 años de edad, es casada y su esposo labora como mensajero, brindando el sustento de vida a la familia, ellos habitan en el Barrio Laureles Norte, tienen tres hijos,  la mayor de 30 años se vale por si misma, pero los otros dos pequeños dependen económicamente de ellos.

Dentro de las prioridades, esta la remodelación de la infraestructura del hogar, es por esto que solicitan de un préstamo para la compra de ventanas y un portón de hierro que refuerce la seguridad del hogar, debido a que ellos habitan en un barrio capitalino que muestra altos índices de delincuencia y amenaza con el buen vivir, esta es la razón de la compra y la inversión que desean llevar a cabo, para la proteccion de los pequeños.
texts.en:
Maria Azucena C. O. is forty-four and married. Her husband works as a courier to support the family. They live in the Laureles Norte neighborhood and have three children. The eldest, who is thirty, is on her own, but the other two little ones are still dependent. Maria's priorities include renovating their home. She is seeking a loan so she can buy windows and an iron gate to reinforce the house's security. Their neighborhood is in the capital, which has a higher crime rate that threatens their well-being. That's why she wants to make the expenditures, to invest in the protection of her little ones.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy windows and an iron gate.

loans.name: Elia

texts.es:
Mi familia es lo mas importante y como madre me preocupa dar lo mejor posible 							
a mis niñas ya que son menores de edad. 

Tengo la necesidad de poner Vitropiso en mi vivienda ya que aparte de 

dar mejor apariencia, es mas higienico y mis muebles se conservan mas limpios, no he podido hacerlo debido a 

que no he logrado juntar el dinero es por eso que ahora les solicito a ustedes el apoyo para poder llevar a 

cabo este proyecto de mejoramiento para mi vivienda.
texts.en:
My family is the most important thing for me and as a mother I'm concerned with giving the best to my young daughters. I need to put a ceramic tile floor in my home which, along with giving a better appearance, is more hygienic and my furniture will stay cleaner. I haven't been able to do it because I haven't been able to save the money. This is why I'm asking you all for help now, to be able to finally undertake my home improvement project.

Translated from Spanish by Shaun Haines, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Installing a ceramic tile floor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of palm oil

loans.name: Normita

texts.en:
Normita M., 52, is married to Gaspar M., a taxi driver. They have two children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has managed her own variety store for quite some time.

Normita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 14,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries, toiletries and beverages needed to replenish and maintain her inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying groceries, toiletries and beverages needed to replenish inventory

loans.name: Cheickna

texts.fr:
Monsieur Cheickna Samaké est une homme marié de 34 et père de 3 enfants. Il réside avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier Massablacoura de Bougouni.
Monsieur Cheickna Samaké est enseignant de profession, et parallèlement à cette profession il excelle dans les activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des œufs. Il a appris cette activité auprès de son ami.
Avec une expérience de 3 ans, il maîtrise son activité et est très apprécié.
Afin de renforcer son capital, il décide de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter  une grandes quantité  d’alvéoles œufs. Il est à sa première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso
Il s’approvisionne chez les fermiers à Sanankoroba, Dialakoroba et des fois à Bamako (Capitale de la  République du Mali).
Les œufs sont vendus  à Bougouni, aux boutiquiers et aux restauratrices .
Avec ce prêt il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 27 000 FCFA.
texts.en:
Mister Cheickna Samaké is 34 years old and the father of 3 children. He lives with his wife and children in the Massablacoura district of Bougouni. Mister Cheickna Samaké is a teacher by profession. At the same time, he excels in income-generating activities such as buying and selling eggs. He learned this activity from his friend. With 3 years of experience, he masters his business and is highly thought of. In order to strengthen his capital, he decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso to buy a large amount of egg flats. This is his first experience with Soro Yiriwaso. He gets his supplies from farmers in Sanankoroba, Dialakoroba and sometimes in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). The eggs are sold in Bougouni to shopkeepers and restaurant owners. With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 27,000 CFA francs.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy eggs

loans.name: Ami

texts.en: Madame Ami A. is 40 years old and sells plastics, dishes, and other items in Lome, Togo. She is married and the mother of one child. Madame Amouve has been selling plastics and other items since 2000. Normally she sells these items from her home, but she also goes to the Adidogome Market in Lome to sell the items to shoppers there. This is Madame Amouve's first loan from WAGES; she is requesting 350,000 CFA in order to purchase more dishes, plastic basins, and other items to sell.

loans.use: To purchase plastics, dishes, and other merchandise

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 27 years old and is married. She is blessed with two children who go to school (they are shown in the photo wearing their school uniforms).

Elizabeth is a hardworking business lady who has been engaged in different businesses. She currently operates a greengrocer’s and a retail shop. She was previously operating a cafeteria. She also operates a transport business for extra income.

Elizabeth is a member of Faulu Kenya and she previously took out a loan of 70,000 KES and repaid it successfully. She has requested another loan of 80,000 KES to buy a cow as she wants to start rearing dairy cows for milk.

Elizabeth hopes to expand her retail shop into a wholesale operation in future.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Tseren-Ochir

texts.en: Tseren-Ochir C. is 30 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Govi-Altay province, western of Mongolia in their own ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. Tseren-Ochir began his meat retailing business in 2008 with the help of his wife. He purchases meat in bulk from surrounding regions and his wife is responsible for the retailing, which she manages at a rented stall in their town market. The two requested a 100,000 MNT loan in 2008 and paid back in full. With their business revenues, they have purchased a small truck, which Tseren-Ochir uses for his transportation business. Both of them are hard-working people who always see a bright future. Tseren-Ochir wants to expand his business, buy a large amount of meat from the countryside during this period when the prices are lower and purchase a yard for his family with his business revenues. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase meat in bulk and resell at higher prices.

loans.use: To purchase meat in bulk

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane N. lives in Bwaise neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has nine children, all of whom are in school. Jane lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and medical expenses.

Jane sells secondhand clothes seven days a week. She has been in business for eight years. She sells her clothes at retail prices at the market. She also owns a motorcycle which brings in additional income.

Jane has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of secondhand clothes. The main business challenges Jane faces include seasonality and transportation. Her goals are to see her business grow larger so she can start selling wholesale only and to also own a delivery van.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand clothes

loans.name: Edwing

texts.es: Edwing, de 29 años, es un hombre trabajador y bueno, tiene dos hermanos pero solo vive con sus padres Aparicio de 60 y Teodora de 55 años, en su casa propia ubicada en la localidad de Palcamayo. Su vida es significado de esfuerzo, más aún que su razón de progreso y triunfo es su hermana Ana que estudia Gastronomía en la capital; motivo por el cual dejó sus estudios de Teología para apoyarla.  Invierte un promedio de mil soles mensuales en ello, por tal motivo se dedica al cultivo de espinaca, zanahoria y habas, siendo lo cosechado llevado al mercado central de su localidad para su respectiva comercialización. Asimismo viaja dos veces por mes a la capital, para vender su producción a los mayoristas, a precios muy buenos que le permiten obtener buenas ganancias. Le gusta atender, regar y fumigar las plantas porque sabe que las hortalizas tiene mayor demanda que otros cultivos, ahora el quiere incursionar en otros campos como la ganadería, ya que desea intensificarse en la ganadería. Es el séptimo crédito con MFP y esta contento de pertenecer a su banco comunal donde puede compartir sus planes de negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará abono y productos para limpiar la planta de avena y lechuga de bacterias.
texts.en:
Edwing, age 29, is a hardworking and good-natured gentleman. He lives in his own home in the town of Palcamayo with his parents Aparacio (age 60) and Teodora (age 55). Edwing also has two siblings who do not live with them. His life is defined by his efforts. He is motivated to succeed so that he can support his sister Ana who is studying culinary sciences in the capital. Edwing dropped out of seminary so that he could support her. He invests approximately 1000 PEN each month into growing spinach, carrots, and beans and brings his produce to the central market in town where he can sell them. In addition, he travels to the capital twice a month to sell his goods to the wholesalers who offer very good prices, which helps him obtain a good income. He enjoys monitoring, watering, and fumigating his crops because vegetables have greater demand than other products. Now he wants to venture into other areas of agriculture, so he plans to intensify his efforts at livestock breeding.

This is his seventh loan with MFP. Edwing is happy to be part of his Communal Bank because the members share their business plans with one another. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy compost and products to rid his oat and lettuce crops of bacteria.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase compost & anti-bacterial products

loans.name: Carmen Rosa

texts.es:
Carmen Rosa es una madre de familia de 37 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus hijos en el sector Aviación del distrito de Tumán una zona agrícola situada a más de veinte minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace diez años a la crianza y venta de animales menores. Ella cría diversas aves como patos, pavos, gallinas y mamíferos como cerdos en algunos corrales instalados en la parte posterior de su domicilio. Los alimenta de granos y pastos naturales y cuando ya han alcanzado un buen punto de desarrollo los ofrece en venta en el mercado Moshoqueque de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Carmen desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más animales y alimento para ampliar sus ventas, sobretodo aprovechando la cercanía de la temporada navideña que es cuando su negocio tiene más ventas, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles.

Carmen es una mujer bastante activa y entregada a su familia. Su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo como empresaria para ayudar a su esposo a mejorar su calidad de vida y salir adelante.
texts.en:
Carmen Rosa, 37, is a mother living with her husband and children in the Aviación section of Tumán district, a farming area located over twenty minutes from the city of Chiclayo.

For the last 10 years Rosa has raised small farm animals.  She raises various kinds of barnyard fowl like ducks, turkeys and chickens as well as mammals like pigs in pens in her back yard.  She feeds them grains and natural grasses and when they reach a good level of development she sells them at the Moshoqueque Market in the city of Chiclayo.

Carmen wants to expand her business buying more animals and feed for them to increase sales especially now that the Christmas season is approaching when her sales are the best.  She has, therefore, decided to request her first, 2000 new sol, loan from Edpyme Alternativa.

Carmen is quite an active woman who is devoted to her family.  Her greatest wish is to continue to grow as a businesswoman to help her husband improve their quality of life and to succeed.

loans.use: To enlarge her business buying more animals and feed for them in order to increase sales.

loans.name: Ta - Taesu - Tekeh Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Ta-Taesu-Tekeh” group from Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan of 800,000 leones each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Isatu L. is the leader of this group. She is a 50-year-old woman, married to an Imam, and they have four children who are no longer attending schools. Isatu has been a businesswoman for many years now. She sells soft drinks, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy crates of soft drinks to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy crates of soft drinks to add to her business

loans.name: Chhe's Group

texts.en:
The group loan consists of four members. They are living in Kandal village, Kandal province. This group selected Mrs. Chhe L., a 58-year-old married woman, as the group leader. All the members of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Chhe L. and her husband, Mr. Chuon Sorn, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate corn and rice for a living. They face a problem because they lack money to support their crops. Thus, Mrs. Chhe L. would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate corn and rice. This couple has two children who are seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate corn and rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase transportation for milk produced on the farm

loans.name: Josefa Ernestina

texts.es: Josefa Ernestina R. M. de 26 años de edad, es una madre y esposa muy responsable, la cual trabaja muy duro para salir adelante. Ella reside en Santiago de María en el departamento de Usulután, en donde vive junto a su esposo quien trabaja como joyero, así mismo vive junto a su pequeño hijo de 2 meses de edad y junto a su madre. Josefa posee una venta de ropa para niñas y niños, así mismo comercializa accesorios como ganchos, diademas, esmaltes y otros más. El negocio se encuentra en el mercado regional y Santiago de María. Josefa solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda surtir el negocio comprando ropa de moda para niños, con dibujos alusivos a caricaturas, así mismo para comprar más cosméticos, ganchos y colas para el cabello. Josefa desea en gran manera mejorar su negocio ya que sus ganancias son fundamentales para el sostenimiento del hogar.
texts.en: Josefa Ernestina R. M. is a very responsible mother and wife, who works very hard to improve her family's circumstances. She lives in Santiago de María in the Usulután department, where she lives with her husband who works as a jeweller, their small son, 2 months old, and her mother. Josefa possesses a children's clothing business, and also sells accessories such as hair ties, tiaras, nail polish and other things. Her business is found in the regional market and Santiago de María. Josefa is seeking a loan so that she can stock her business, purchasing more quantities of fashionable boys clothes, with drawings and cartoons on them, and also purchase more cosmetics, hair ties and headbands. Josefa has a great desire to improve her business as her earnings are fundamental to sustaining her home.

loans.use: Purchase clothing and hair accessories

location.town: Santiago de María, departamento de Usulután

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia D. is 54 years old, married, and supports her family by operating two business ventures:  general store and buying & selling charcoal businesses. She lives at 111, Brgy. Dancalan, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her general store and buying & selling charcoal businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7,300. Virginia is now borrowing PHP 21,000 so that she could continue to purchase more stock to sell.  This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Virginia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell to her customers

loans.name: Imad

texts.en:
Imad is a young man from Rafah city in Gaza Strip, Imad is married and a father of one son, Wadee, and one daughter, Rinad. Imad is a National Palestinian Authority employee. He was married four years ago and has been purchasing the needed items gradually.

Imad came to FATEN and took a loan to buy a washing machine to replace the old one they had, which was a second hand machine and is not working properly anymore, and other household needs.

Imad appears in the picture here in FATEN's branch.

loans.use: To purchase a washing machine

loans.name: Nargis' Group

texts.en:
Nargis lives in Kamoki, which is a small city of Punjab Pakistan and famous for its agriculture industry.  She lives there with her family in the area named Khan piyara, in a 2 room brick house. She moved there after her marriage. She is married to B. M. who has a construction supply business at the market. He offers his services to different construction companies and to regular customers and earns a good income by completing their orders on time. 

Nargis has given birth to 2 sons and a daughter. Her elder son has a sanitary supply business, while her younger one works in a factory.  
Nargis herself is a talented lady who owns & operates an embroider business at her home. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband. She receives orders from the neighboring customers and earns a good income by completing them on time. Her daughter also helps her in her embroider business. 

Nargis has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her embroidery business. She will utilize the loan money in buying embroidery material such as beads, colored thread and material in bulk which will help her offer more variety to her clients and in increasing her income as well.  

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan years, she has established a good credit behavior and never missed a loan group meeting. 

Note: "In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nargis".

loans.use: To buy embroidery material for her  business

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es: Elsa tiene 46 años vive con uno de sus hijos en su casa propia. Desde hace 6 años se dedica a la venta de productos de primera necesidad, negocio que lo tiene instalado desde la comodidad de su casa; desde entonces atiende todos los días, siendo más las ventas por las mañanas. En ocasiones su hija la ayuda en la atención hacía los clientes. Por otro lado, una de las actividades que le gusta también desarrollar es la agricultura, ya que le permite tener ganancias que le ayuda para el sustento de su familia. Por ahora lo que más desea es abastecer su tienda con diversos productos.  Es su crédito numero 2 con MFP, esta muy contento de  saber que tiene un apoyo financiero ya que siempre ha demostrado  ser responsable en sus pagos, además  le agrada ser parte de su banco comunal porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias, agradece  a aquellas personas que serán gestoras del préstamo que solicita y le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra de más abarrotes.
texts.en: Elsa is 46 years old and lives with her two children in their own house. For the past six years she has been selling basic necessities. This business is conveniently located in her house. She works here everyday. She has the most sales in the mornings. Sometimes her daughter helps her attend to her customers. On the other hand, another activity that she also likes is agriculture, as it also gives her earnings that she uses to support her family. Right now, what she would like to do is stock her store with a greater variety of products. This is her second loan with MFP. She is happy to know that she has the support of this financial organization. She has always been responsible with her payments. Also she is thankful for the community bank because all of the members are responsible and supportive. She is thankful for the people that are providing her with this loan that she is requesting.
